Award.AwardTitle: Strengthening Qualitative Research through Methodological Innovation and Integration: Assimilation and Transition to Early Adulthood for Mexican Americans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES- 1026580
Robert Courtney Smith
CUNY Baruch College

This project studies the experience of assimilation and transition to early adulthood for Mexican Americans in New York, drawing on fourteen years of ethnographic research and using new methodological approaches. The project will analyze data gathered by the PI on children of Mexican immigrants in New York at work, in school and in their social and personal lives. This project draws on long term ethnographic and interview research to that will be analyzed to study the mechanisms through which immigrant youth use to become more or less upwardly mobile as they enter early adulthood. The project uses new methods to examine assimilation and mobility in the transition to early adulthood. Specifically, it applies a case oriented logic of analysis to ethnographic data to transform it into synopses and then into numbers so it may be analyzed using new techniques. The PI has developed the Lifecourse Multidimensional Analytical Protocol (LMAP) which arranges qualitative data so it can be used for Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA).

Broader Impact

The project will contribute to the integration of qualitative and quantitative methodological approaches. Further, the findings will contribute insight into developing CUNY (City University of New York) programs that promote college attendance among children of immigrants and other youth

Institution.Name: CUNY Baruch College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE LAO MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 This research has produced positive outcomes for sociological inquiry, and for the broader society, that is, it has contributed to the larger, public issues the research engages. A first positive outcome will be a book, Horatio Alger Lives in Brooklyn, But Check His Papers. This book is currently under contract with the University of California Press, and will be handed in for review during 2014. The book analyzes the data, outcomes and methods of over 15 years of research following these children of immigrants as they moved through adolescence into early and even full adulthood. Second, the research has produced a number of scholarly articles and papers, one of which is under review at the American Sociological Review, and others of which are in development. Third, the project has helped to train Doctoral and Masters level students in research methods, giving them the tools to think through both case oriented research, with its complex causality, and variable oriented research, with its net effects causality. The LMAP (Lifecourse Multidimensional Analytical Protocol) is designed to meet a significant challenge in ethnographic research -- how to include all the cases in one's dataset in the analysis at the same time. Usually, ethnographic work theorizes off the most interesting cases, taking advantage of the sociological insights that can be possible with breaks in normal social structures. The LMAP also overcomes limitations in most net effects research, which seeks to find out how much effect is contributed, ceteris paribus, by a given variable, on average, for a whole population. The LMAP uses qualitative comparative analysis to analyze which combinations of conditions are associated with which outcomes, and uses closer case analysis of those types to determine how causality works. Fourth, the research has produced two databases, for which the cases are currently being finished in their coding, one for case oriented work -- the LMAP -- and the other for variable oriented work (the variable oriented database). Fifth, the work here has informed the work of CUNY and the New York City Board of Education (BOE) as they work with the Mexican community, and with Mexican community organizations, as they seek to promote the educational achievement of Mexican and other students in New York. Other organizations promoting educational achievement among children of immigrants have also discussed using this approach in their evaluations. Last Modified: 05/01/2013 Submitted by: Robert C Smith
